Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Molecular Mechanisms of Virus-vector Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many of the viruses that infect humans, animals, and plants are transmitted from one host to another by insects and other arthropods. Arthropods can serve as vectors and hosts for the viruses that they transmit, and in some cases, viruses induce behavioral and physiological changes in hosts that facilitate transmission. The central aim of the project is to identify vector molecules that recognize and respond to virus infection and characterize the direct effect of virus infection on arthropod vectors. The central hypothesis is that the insect immune system is activated by viruses resulting in successful transmission to animal and plant hosts with little to no virulence to the vector. The project will address this hypothesis by developing a fundamental understanding of the vector response to virus infection, identifying vector proteins that interact directly with the virus during the infection cycle, and exploring the possible links between vector physiology and behaviors to virus infection status. The project results are expected to contribute to our understanding of how some organisms can tolerate or fight off viral pathogens. These findings may lead to the development of novel strategies to prevent transmission of viruses and/or the identification of unique molecules to combat virus diseases.

The broader impacts of the proposal are the contribution to education of the general public on basic scientific principals which will enable them to make informed decisions regarding scientific technologies that directly impact them. The investigator will develop an interactive exhibit entitled "Arthropods as Vectors" for the Kansas State University Insect Zoo that will be displayed for the duration of the CAREER award. New teaching tools incorporating virology and virus-vector interactions in middle school science curricula will be prepared and made publicly available on the World Wide Web. The award will enable the training of the next generation of scientists and enhance diversity by mentoring undergraduate students from underrepresented groups as they conduct research projects on the physiological outcomes of virus infection of arthropod vectors. Additionally, a scientist-science fair participant "pen pal" program targeted to students in rural locations will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Viruses are parasites of humans, animals, plants, microorganisms and even other viruses. Plant-infecting viruses cause significant yield losses to food crops around the world and virus diseases make up 47% of new emerging plant diseases. As such, plant viruses are a major threat to global food security, drawing attention to the need for developing effective and long-lasting strategies for controlling virus spread through our agricultural landscapes. The majority of plant-pathogenic viruses are transmitted and spread plant-to-plant by arthropod vectors (e.g., whiteflies, thrips, mites), and while the plant succumbs to disease caused by virus infection, most vector partners that harbor and/or proliferate the plant viruses in their bodies remain virtually unharmed. For vector biologists, understanding the intimate associations between virus and arthropod vector is paramount for developing new technologies that disrupt transmission of the virus to plants. The central aim of this proposal was to identify the vector molecules that recognize and respond to virus infection and characterize the direct effect of virus infection on arthropod vectors. We used the Peregrinus maidis (corn planthopper) - Maize mosaic rhabdovirus (MMV) system of agronomic importance as a model to study vector-virus interactions. Our study revealed that virus accumulated significantly inside the planthopper body over time and throughout insect development from nymphs through adulthood. Sustained virus infection over the lifespan of vector indicates a potentially high capacity of this insect to transmit and spread virus to plants for extended periods of time during its lifespan. To gain insight into insect response and virus persistence in the planthopper, we compared gene expression of infected and non-infected adults. Comparison with other virus-hopper systems revealed some responses unique to the corn planthopper-MMV system, and a core set of shared and perhaps universal responses to viruses that propagate in their hopper partners. This study contributes to our understanding of how some organisms can tolerate or fight off viral pathogens, and furthers our knowledge of genes and cellular processes associated with insect defense responses to viruses, particularly for viruses that replicate inside the bodies of their living vectors. Further study of these insect genes and processes may lead to insights into molecular determinants of vector specificity (evolved partnerships in nature) and identification of new strategies aimed at breaking up the partnership in order to diminish virus diseases in the future. Our studies also lead to identification of insect proteins that directly interact with the viral protein that allows the virus to enter insect cells. Surprisingly, the virus protein interacted with more than 100 insect proteins which are involved in a wide range of cellular processes. This information gives us important clues about virus-host specificity and helps us identify targets for biotechnology innovations or products that can be developed to prevent virus spread and manage diseases.

With this project, we created new learning opportunities for the general public, and we enhanced learning for postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students. The research approaches and findings were incorporated into courses where students created i) educational YouTube videos targeted towards elementary and middle school children and ii) Wikipedia pages for emerging plant viruses. We also developed two outreach activities for preK-8th graders entitled “Discovering the hidden world of viruses” and “Plants get sick too.” An educational poster was created for the KSU Insect Zoo and Open House. Over the project time span, the “Little Insects, BIG Diseases” display was viewed by more than 5,000 people. We hosted eight undergraduate researchers for either year-long or intensive summer experiential-learning opportunities studying virus-host interactions. Of the undergraduate participants, seven were female and six were from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Our goals of increasing scientific literacy of the general public and training the next generation of inclusive and diverse science professionals were met.
